MINUTE ORDER, Motions terminated: 58 MOTION to Dismiss filed by Bryan King, Robert Herzog, Bea Blowers, EK, Brad Simpson, Asin, Julie Martin, Jones, Robinson.The following MINUTE ORDER is made by direction of the Court, the Honorable Ricardo S. Martinez, Chief United States District Judge: On September 4, 2018, certain Defendants filed a Motion to Dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6). Dkt. #58. Eight days later, on September 12, 2018, Plaintiffs filed an Amended Complaint. Dkt. #59. Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15 states that a party may amend its pleading once as a matter of course within 21 days of original service, or 21 days after service of a responsive pleading or a motion under Rule 12(b), (e), or (f). Accordingly, the Amended Complaint is procedurally valid and renders the pending Motion to Dismiss, Dkt. #58, moot. The Court hereby STRIKES that Motion. (COB) (Entered: 10/03/2018)

case_data.name: Roberts v. Sinclair
case_data.plaintiff_description: Prisoners at the Monroe Correctional Complex who are practicing Muslims.
case_data.summary:
A group of practicing Muslim prisoners at the Monroe Correctional Complex filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington on June 10, 2018, alleging that prison staff deprived them of nighttime meals while they were fasting during Ramadan. Represented by the Center for American-Islamic Relations (CAIR), they brought this action against the Washington State Department of Corrections (DOC) and sought declaratory and emergency injunctive relief. According to the plaintiffs, despite their requests, the prison chaplain refused to add them to a list of prisoners to be served specially-timed meals during the month of Ramadan (โthe Ramadan Listโ), in effect subjecting them to a โstarvation policyโ because the normal schedule for meals at the prison all fell within the time of day when they are fasting. They alleged that this violated the First Amendment's Free Exercise Clause, the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, the Eighth Amendmentโs ban on cruel and unusual punishment, and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA).

Along with their complaint, the plaintiffs also filed a motion for a temporary restraining order that would force the prison to provide them with legally adequate meals through the end of Ramadan; that motion was granted by District Judge Ronald B. Leighton the same day.

In its answer, the DOC denied virtually all of the pertinent allegations in the complaint. It disputed the plaintiffsโ contention that it refused to add them to the Ramadan List, maintaining that the prisoners had not signed up during the established sign-up period. It denied the existence of a โstarvation policyโ towards Muslims at the prison. Finally, it made a number of different affirmative defenses, including qualified immunity for state government officials. The case has been assigned to District Judge Ricardo S. Martinez.

The defendants filed a motion to dismiss on September 4, 2018. On October 3, 2018, in light of the plaintiffs' amended complaint, submitted on September 12, 2018, the court dismissed the defendants' motion as moot. The parties began discovery in preparation for the trial, scheduled for October 7, 2019.

The defendants moved for summary judgment on July 9, 2019. Their motion asserted that the plaintiffs had failed to exhaust administrative remedies before filing their amended complaint. Defendants also argued that the sign-up procedures for the "Ramadan List" did not significantly burden the plaintiffs' religious beliefs and served a compelling government interest, making the RLUIPA claims not viable. They defendants further asserted that they were entitled to qualified immunity on the constitutional claims.

The plaintiffs filed their own motion for summary judgment that same day. Their brief reasserted an argument for the validity of their RLUIPA claims, the 8th Amendment claim, and their Equal Protection and Free Exercise claim. They also argued that the defendants should not be entitled to qualified immunity.

The court granted the defendants motion for summary judgment on September 6, 2019 and dismissed all of the plaintiffs' claims as moot. 2019 WL 4246981. Defendants filed for costs on September 27, 2019. Their request was granted in part and denied in part on October 22, 2019.

The plaintiffs appealed the order granting the defendants motion for summary judgment to the Ninth Circuit. On December 29, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the decision. The Ninth Circuit found that the plaintiffs had failed to exhaust their available administrative remedies, and therefore could not bring their claims in court. The case is now closed.
case_data.summary_short: In June 2018, a group of Muslim prisoners at the Monroe Correctional Complex who were fasting during Ramadan filed this lawsuit against the Washington State Department of Corrections (DOC) in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. They alleged that prison staff subjected them to a "starvation policy" by refusing to provide them with meals outside of the hours in which they were fasting, in violation of the First, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLUIPA). The same day they filed their complaint, the plaintiffs obtained a temporary restraining order ordering the prison to provide them with legally adequate meals meeting their religious needs through the end of Ramadan. The DOC denied all of the pertinent allegations in its answer filed in July 2018. The case is still ongoing.

10/03/2018  62   MINUTE ORDER, Motions terminated: 58 MOTION to Dismiss filed by 
Bryan King, Robert Herzog, Bea Blowers, EK, Brad Simpson, Asin, Julie 
Martin, Jones, Robinson.The following MINUTE ORDER is made by 
direction of the Court, the Honorable Ricardo S. Martinez, Chief United 
States District Judge: On September 4, 2018, certain Defendants filed a 
Motion to Dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6). Dkt. #58. Eight days later, on 
September 12, 2018, Plaintiffs filed an Amended Complaint. Dkt. #59. 
Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15 states that a party may amend its 
pleading once as a matter of course within 21 days of original service, or 
21 days after service of a responsive pleading or a motion under Rule 
12(b), (e), or (f). Accordingly, the Amended Complaint is procedurally 
valid and renders the pending Motion to Dismiss, Dkt. #58, moot. The 
Court hereby STRIKES that Motion. (COB) (Entered: 10/03/2018)

10/03/2018  62   MINUTE ORDER, Motions terminated: 58 MOTION to Dismiss filed by 
Bryan King, Robert Herzog, Bea Blowers, EK, Brad Simpson, Asin, Julie 
Martin, Jones, Robinson.The following MINUTE ORDER is made by 
direction of the Court, the Honorable Ricardo S. Martinez, Chief United 
States District Judge: On September 4, 2018, certain Defendants filed a 
Motion to Dismiss under Rule 12(b)(6). Dkt. #58. Eight days later, on 
September 12, 2018, Plaintiffs filed an Amended Complaint. Dkt. #59. 
Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 15 states that a party may amend its 
pleading once as a matter of course within 21 days of original service, or 
21 days after service of a responsive pleading or a motion under Rule 
12(b), (e), or (f). Accordingly, the Amended Complaint is procedurally 
valid and renders the pending Motion to Dismiss, Dkt. #58, moot. The 
Court hereby STRIKES that Motion. (COB) (Entered: 10/03/2018)

9  DEMARIO ROBERTS, et al.,  NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT 
   
10    Plaintiffs,  DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR 
  SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
11    v.   
  NOTE ON MOTION CALENDAR: 
12  STEPHEN SINCLAIR, et al.,  August 2, 2019 
   
13    Defendants. 
   
14 
Defendants  STEPHEN  SINCLAIR,  ERIC  ASKREN,  JAMIE  DOLAN,  HENRI 
15 
FISCHER,  PETE  MAXSON,  MIKE  OBENLAND,  JAMES  PARKS,  STEFAN  ROSE, 
16 
DAVID SHERMAN, BELINDA STEWART, and JEFF UTTECHT,1 by and through their 
17 
attorneys,  respectfully  move  for  an  order  granting  summary  judgment  and  dismissing 
18 
Plaintiffsโ claims with prejudice.  
19 
I.  INTRODUCTION & RELIEF REQUESTED 
20 
  Plaintiffs are five individuals who are currently or were previously in Washington 
21 
Department  of  Corrections  (DOC)  custody.  Plaintiffs  allege  Defendants  violated  their 
22 
constitutional  rights  and  RLUIPA  by  denying  them  the  opportunity  to  participate  in  the 
23 
Ramadan meal program and having a Ramadan meal program that requires individuals to sign 
24 
                                                 
25 
1 Plaintiffsโ amended complaint lists an โUnidentified Chaplainโ as a Defendant. ECF No. 59, at 3 & 7. It 
is unclear who Plaintiffs are referencing. Because the arguments raised in this motion would apply equally to this 
26 
unidentified person and this person has not been served, dismissal of all claims is still appropriate. 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  1  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 2 of 25
 
1  up months in advance of Ramadan. Defendants seek dismissal of Plaintiffsโ claims. Contrary to 
2  the statements in Plaintiffsโ complaint and ex parte motion for a temporary restraining order, 
3  the original four plaintiffs failed to exhaust their administrative remedies and John James did 
4  not exhaust until after Plaintiffs filed their amended complaint. As such, all of Plaintiffsโ 
5  claims can be dismissed for failure to exhaust.2  
6    On the merits, Plaintiffsโ challenge to DOCโs Ramadan policy fails as a matter of law. 
7  Requiring inmates to complete and submit a simple form to participate in a religious event 
8  does not impose any substantial burden on Plaintiffsโ religious beliefs. To the extent that 
9  completing a form that takes less than five minutes imposes a substantial burden, the sign-up 
10  process  serves  compelling  government  interests.  As  such,  Plaintiffs  do  not  have  viable 
11  RLUIPA claims. Furthermore, any claims for injunctive reliefโto the extent such claims are 
12  viableโare now moot. Finally, because Defendants are entitled to qualified immunity on the 
13  constitutional claims and there is no monetary liability on RLUIPA claims, all claims for 
14  monetary damages must also be dismissed. Therefore, the Court should dismiss Plaintiffsโ 
15  claims with prejudice 
16 
II.  STATEMENT OF FACTS 
17 
A.  DOCโs Food Service Program 
18    DOC's food service program is unlike any other. DOC has to account for the dietary 
19  needs of all 18,000 individuals in its custody. Declaration of Bryan King (King Dec.), at ยถ 1. 
20  This requires sourcing, preparing, and providing 50,000 meals each day. King Dec., at ยถ 1. 
21  DOC  accomplishes  this  task  within  the  unique  confines  of  prison,  where  activities  and 
22  movement of inmates are highly regulated to ensure the safety and security of DOC staff and 
                                                 
23 
2 When this case was first filed, the parties focused on Plaintiffsโ allegations regarding their weight loss. 
24  As explained in Defendantsโ motion to dissolve and their response to Plaintiffsโ motion to amend and motion to 
extend discovery, there are many reasons to be skeptical of Plaintiffsโ claims of weight loss. For purposes of 
Defendantsโ summary judgment motion, however, these allegations are not material because they do not affect the 
25 
legal analysis and there is no indication that any Defendant was aware of their claimed weight loss prior to the 
filing of this lawsuit. Defendants reserve the right to file an appropriate motion in the future regarding these 
26 
claims of weight loss that appear to be unsupported. 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  2  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 3 of 25
 
1  incarcerated individuals. Id. DOC offers five standard diets (mainline, a vegetarian mainline 
2  alternative, a milk mainline alternative, Kosher, and Halal) as well as a variety of medically 
3  prescribed  therapeutic  diets  (Consistent Carbohydrate  (Diabetic),  Lower  Protein,  Low  K+ 
4  (Renal), Mechanical Soft, No Gluten, No Peanut, No Tomato, Metabolic (lighter fare), Puree, 
5  and Liquid diets). King Declaration, at ยถ 2. To provide these diets and ensure consistency 
6  across facilities, DOC plans the diets centrally, and they are reviewed by the Dietary Services 
7  Manager to ensure they meet dietary guidelines. Id.; Declaration of Counsel (Counsel Dec.), 
8  Ex. 1, Brent Carney Deposition, at 19:18-25, 23:12-21. DOCโs menu is intended to meet 
9  nutritional standards identified in DOC policy that are based on the Dietary Guidelines for 
10  Americans. Counsel Dec., Ex. 1, at 26:2-17, 31:1-12, 31:22-32:4; King Dec., at ยถ 2. 
11    Although DOC facilities do not establish their own menus, they are responsible for 
12  ordering the food needed to serve the menus. King Dec., at ยถ 4. The Monroe Correctional 
13  Complex (MCC), where Plaintiffs were housed in 2018, serves approximately 2,400 inmates in 
14  the five separate prison facilities. Declaration of Linda Heise (Heise Dec.), at ยถ 1. Because of 
15  the volume of food that MCC provides (approximately 7,000 meals per day), the number of 
16  special diets that require accommodation, and the fact that DOC needs to meet the nutritional 
17  and dietary needs of those in its custody, strict adherence to policy is required. Id. 
18 
B.  DOCโs Ramadan Meal Program 
19    DOC has a longstanding practice of accommodating the religious beliefs and practices 
20  of its incarcerated population, including by providing meals to Muslim inmates who fast during 
21  Ramadan. ECF No. 16, Declaration of Belinda Stewart (Stewart Dec.), at ยถ 3 & Ex. 1. At 
22  various times over the years, DOC has sought the input of Muslim community members, 
23  including CAIR Washington, regarding the development of a halal diet and the Ramadan meal 
24  program. ECF No. 16, Stewart Dec., at ยถ 8; King Dec., at ยถ 3. In the tightly controlled prison 
25  environment, accommodating religious practices requires that incarcerated individuals follow 
26  established process and procedure so that DOC knows who wishes to participate in a particular 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  3  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 4 of 25
 
1  religious event and can make necessary custody, food service, and other plans for the event. 
2  ECF No. 16, Stewart Dec., at ยถยถ 5 & 7. 
3    DOCโs Ramadan meal program accommodates Muslim inmates who wish to fast for 
4  Ramadan by providing meals for Muslim inmates to break their fast. Heise Dec., at ยถ 6; King 
5  Dec.,  at  ยถ  6.  As  with  other  meals,  DOC  centrally  develops  a  Ramadan  menu  to  ensure 
6  consistency and DOC staff perform a nutritional analysis to ensure that the menu meets dietary 
7  guidelines. Counsel Dec., Ex. 1, at 23:18-21. DOCโs Ramadan menu meets the daily caloric 
8  requirements for inmates of 2,600 to 2,900 calories. Counsel Dec., Ex. 1, at 31:22-32:6. The 
9  caloric and nutritional content in the Ramadan menu is comparable to the nutritional and 
10  caloric content of DOCโs mainline menu. Counsel Dec., Ex. 1, at 62:24-64:3. 
11    The Ramadan meals are Halal and consist of a fasting tray and a microwavable hot 
12  meal. Heise Dec., at ยถ 6; King Dec., at ยถ 6. The fasting tray includes: two sandwiches (turkey 
13  or bologna and peanut butter and jelly), a whole grain muffin, whole grain cookies, an oatmeal 
14  packet, powdered milk, chips, a breakfast bar, dates, and condiments. Heise Dec., at ยถ 6; King 
15  Dec., at ยถ 6. The tray also includes supplements of hard-boiled eggs, fresh fruit, and veggie 
16  sticks. King Dec., at ยถ 6. The microwavable hot meal is manufactured โTV dinnerโ style and 
17  contains a protein entrรฉe, hot vegetable, and starch. Id. For example, the microwavable hot 
18  meal may contain breaded fish, Halal chicken patty, Halal turkey casserole, or Halal beef with 
19  gravy. Heise Dec., at ยถ 6. All meals come with a starch, fresh vegetables, and a fresh fruit. Id. 
20  Although the microwavable hot meal is the same hot meal offered to inmates on the Halal diet, 
21  production of the Halal meals is on a much greater scale leading up to Ramadan because there 
22  typically are 500 or more inmates who participate in Ramadan, but only 100 or so who are on 
23  the Halal diet at any given time. King Dec., at ยถ 6. Also, the fasting trays contain items that are 
24  not served year round. Id. 
25    DOCโs Ramadan meal program is designed to ensure that all inmates receive the same 
26  Ramadan meals. DOC has not traditionally provided alternative meals to inmates in place of 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  4  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 5 of 25
 
1  the Ramadan meals. Instead, when an inmate is on a medical/therapeutic diet, the medical diet 
2  supersedes any religious diet absent an inmate signing a form to refuse the medical diet. King 
3  Declaration, at ยถ 11. As such, DOC typically provides the medical diet over the religious diet. 
4  Id. DOC has also not created hybrid medical/religious diets. Id. Blending therapeutic and 
5  religious diets would raise significant health and logistical concerns. Id. Not only would it be 
6  difficult to logistically manage, it creates the risk that kitchen staff make an error in providing 
7  the inmate an meal suited to his individual medical needs. Id. 
8    DOC puts significant planning into the Ramadan meal program in order to accomplish 
9  the task of providing nutritionally adequate Ramadan meals while also meeting the needs of 
10  the entirety of the DOCโs population. ECF No. 16, Stewart Dec., at ยถ 7. To accommodate the 
11  provision of fasting trays, DOCโs Correctional Industries sources and purchases the food from 
12  vendors and then assembles the meals in time to ensure that the meals are available for 
13  Ramadan. King Dec., at ยถ 7. This requires DOC to prepare and have ready more than 30,000 
14  special meals for the month-long Ramadan observance. King Dec., at ยถ 7. Again, all of this 
15  work is in addition to the feeding of the remaining inmate population and other religious feasts, 
16  including  Passover  (which  in  recent  years  is  close  in  time  with  Ramadan,  requiring 
17  contemporaneous planning for the two observances). King Dec., at ยถ 7; Heise Dec., at ยถ 5.  
18    To facilitate the planning necessary for DOC to accommodate the needs of Muslim 
19  inmates who wish to fast during Ramadan, there is an established sign-up process. The sign-up 
20  process is simple: complete a one page form that Plaintiffs estimate would take fewer than five 
21  minutes to complete and return it to the Chaplain. ECF No. 16, at ยถ 5; Counsel Dec., Ex. 2, 
22  Roberts Deposition, at 41:6-7; Counsel Dec., Ex. 5, Livingston Deposition, at 54:19-55:3; 
23  Counsel Dec., Ex. 4, Mohamed Deposition, at 27:5-15. This sign-up process occurs several 
24  months in advance of Ramadan to allow DOC to produce the meals in time for Ramadan. King 
25  Dec., at ยถ 8. This advance planning allows DOC facilities to order in advance and ensure that 
26  they receive the correct amount of food in time for Ramadan. Heise Dec., at ยถ 9. If there were 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  5  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 6 of 25
 
1  not advance planning and ordering of food, DOC would run the risk of not having adequate 
2  food in time for the event. Id. The 2018 Ramadan sign-up process began in January. On 
3  January  16,  2018,  DOC  notified  the  incarcerated  population  of  the  requirements  for 
4  participation through a written memo. ECF No. 16, Stewart Dec., at ยถ 6 & Ex. 2. The memo 
5  was posted and made readily available to inmates. ECF No. 16 Stewart Dec., at ยถยถ 5-7; 
6  Declaration of David Sherman (Sherman Dec.), at ยถ 4. As it pertains to the Washington State 
7  Reformatory (WSR) at MCC, the memo was posted in hallways in the units where inmates 
8  pass every day and in the activity centers. Sherman Dec., at ยถ 4; Counsel Dec., Ex. 7, at 15:9-
9  17:15. In addition, Chaplain Sherman sent a copy of the memo and a sign-up form to inmates 
10  that had been participating in Muslim religious programming. Sherman Dec., at ยถ 4; Counsel 
11  Dec., Ex. 7, at 15:9-16:3.  
12    Once the sign-up period closed, religious programs  staff compiled  and distributed 
13  participant lists to each facility and the facility Chaplains would post the list so that individuals 
14  could confirm their presence on the list or request to be added if they believed they were 
15  inappropriately left off. ECF No. 16, Stewart Dec., at ยถ 6 & Ex. 2. As it pertains to MCC/WSR, 
16  Sherman periodically posted a list of inmates from whom he had received forms and approved 
17  prior to the expiration of the sign-up period and posted another list after the end of the sign-up 
18  period. Sherman Dec., at ยถ 6. Sherman also met with inmate Muslim leaders, including James, 
19  to go over the list of inmates who had been approved to participate in Ramadan in February 
20  2018. Counsel Dec., Ex. 7, at 40:23-44:12. Of the Plaintiffs, only Jamesโ name was on the list 
21  of individuals who had signed up to participate in February. Sherman Dec., Ex. 2. 
22 
C.  Plaintiffsโ Individual Participation in the Ramadan Meal Program 
23    As discussed in more detail below, all five Plaintiffs were inmates in DOCโs custody 
24  during both the sign-up period for Ramadan 2018 and Ramadan 2018. Other than John James, 
25  Plaintiffs did not submit the required paperwork to participate in the Ramadan meal program 
26  and did not raise the issue with any DOC staff until the eve of Ramadan. 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  6  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 7 of 25
 
1  1.  Plaintiff Demario Roberts   
2  Roberts has been in DOC custody since May 2017 and was housed at MCC from June 
3  2017 until May 2019. Counsel Dec., Ex. 2, at 6:2-4, 8:4-6; Counsel Dec., Ex. 3. He has not 
4  requested a religious diet during his incarceration. Roberts indicates he has not requested a 
5  halal meal because he does not like DOC food and โjust donโt eat here.โ Counsel Dec., Ex. 2, 
6  at 20:21-21:5. DOC did not receive a Ramadan meal request form from Roberts in 2018. ECF 
7  No. 16, Stewart Dec. ยถ 12; Sherman Dec., at ยถ 6. Because DOC did not receive a form, Roberts 
8  was not on the list of approved inmates that was given to fellow John James in February 2018. 
9  Sherman Dec., Ex. 2. There is no evidence that Roberts communicated with Sherman about his 
10  desire to be on the list prior to the first day of Ramadan, May 16. ECF No. 20-1, at 11.3 
11  On May 21, 2018, DOC received a grievance from Roberts that he was not receiving 
12  Ramadan meals. ECF No. 17, Declaration of Peter Maxson (Maxson Dec.), at ยถ 7 & Ex. 2. 
13  Maxson  interviewed  Roberts  that  day  and  asked  Roberts  whether  he  signed  up  for  the 
14  Ramadan meal program. Id. Roberts responded he had not. ECF No. 17, Maxson Dec. at ยถ 7. 
15  Maxson also asked Roberts whether he had seen the sign-up information posted in January. Id. 
16  Roberts said he had, but that he did not submit the required form. Id. Maxson asked Roberts if 
17  he agreed to informally resolve the grievance on that basis, and the grievance was marked 
18  informally resolved at Level 0. Id. Roberts did not appeal or pursue the grievance further. Id. 
19  2.  Plaintiff Mohamed Mohamed 
20    Mohamed entered DOC custody in 2015. Counsel Dec., Ex. 4, Mohamed Deposition, at 
21  9:13-14. He was housed at the Coyote Ridge Corrections Center in 2016 and 2017, where he 
22  signed up for and participated in the Ramadan meal program. Stewart Dec., at ยถ 13; Counsel 
23  Dec.,  Ex.  4,  at  22:19-25.  Mohamed  transferred  to  MCC  in  December  2017  and  had  an 
24  anticipated earned early release date in May. Stewart Dec., at ยถ 13; Counsel Dec., Ex. 4, at 
25  16:16-18. However, in April 2018, while housed in the minimum security unit, Mohamed 
                                                 
26

1  received a serious infraction for violating WAC 137-25-030(603) โ Introducing or transferring 
2  any unauthorized drug or drug paraphernalia โ based on evidence that Mohamed had conspired 
3  to introduce marijuana and spice into the prison. Stewart Dec., at ยถ 13. A hearings officer 
4  found Mohamed guilty of the infraction and sanctioned him to a loss of 30 days of good 
5  conduct time. Stewart Dec., at ยถ 13. This extended his early release date past Ramadan, to June 
6  20, 2018, and he was demoted to the medium custody unit at MCC. Stewart Dec., at ยถ 13. 
7    There is no evidence that Mohamed gave a Ramadan meal sign-up form to a Chaplain 
8  at MCC. Records show that on May 2, 2018, after Mohamedโs release date was extended, he 
9  sent an electronic kiosk message to the Chaplain and asked โCan I get put on Ramadan List? I 
10  missed the deadline...โ ECF No. 20-1, at 16. The Chaplain responded that it was too late to 
11  sign up. ECF No. 20-1, at 17. Mohamed responded by saying โI didnt (sic) have a choice 
12  because I lost good time, 30 days. I have to get on that list. Religious purposes cause I will not 
13  go too mainline. Thank you.โ ECF No. 20-1, at 18.  
14    Mohamed  filed  a  grievance  on  May  16,  2018.  ECF  No.  17-1,  at  41.  Maxson 
15  investigated  the  grievance,  determined  DOC  had  no  record  of  Mohamed  submitting  the 
16  Ramadan form, and concluded that Mohamed could not be given the requested relief as a 
17  result. ECF No. 17-1, Maxson Dec., at ยถ 8 & Ex. 3. Mohamed did not appeal the grievance 
18  response. Id. Mohamed purchased a significant amount of food from the commissary, and 
19  items Mohamed received on May 17, 2018, included ten packages of white rice, ten packages 
20  of cheesy rice and beans, cheese, summer sausages, cookies, Doritos, potato chips, a hot 
21  pickle, and swiss rolls. ECF No. 21, Declaration of Matthew Blair (Blair Dec.), Ex. 7. 
22 
3.  Plaintiff Jeremy Livingston 
23    Livingston reentered DOC custody at the Washington Corrections Center (WCC) on 
24  January 18, 2018. Counsel Dec., Ex. 5, Livingston Deposition, at 11:11-13; ECF No. 16, 
25  Stewart Dec., at ยถ 14. He requested a Halal diet in February 2018. ECF No. 16, Stewart Dec., 
26  at ยถ 14. Livingston had previously been incarcerated with DOC from October 2015 to June 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  8  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 9 of 25
 
1  2017 and was familiar with the Ramadan sign-up process through this prior incarceration. 
2  Counsel Dec., Ex. 5, at 11:17-12:15, 51:16-18. Livingston did not sign up for Ramadan during 
3  the Ramadan sign-up period. Counsel Dec., Ex. 5, at 51:19-52:20. 
4    On May 15, 2018, Livingston sent a kiosk message to the Chaplain asking to be placed 
5  on call out for Ramadan night studies and stating he had not been placed on the Ramadan List. 
6  ECF No. 20-1, at 6. Livingston sent another message on May 17, 2018, asking to be put on the 
7  Ramadan List. Id. The Chaplain responded and indicated he had no record of Livingston 
8  signing up for Ramadan and that he (the Chaplain) had emailed the WCC Chaplain to see if 
9  there  was  a  record  of  Livingston  signing  up  while  at  WCC.  Id.  The  Chaplain  asked  if 
10  Livingston had a record showing he had signed up, and Livingston responded โI left WCC 
11  before I could sign up plus it was too far before Ramadan even started. Is there anyway you 
12  can accomodadate (sic) me for Ramadan?โ Id. In follow up, the Chaplain confirmed that notice 
13  of the Ramadan sign-up process was posted in all living units at WCC, and that there was no 
14  record of correspondence from Livingston to the WCC Chaplain requesting participation in the 
15  Ramadan meal program. ECF No. 20-1, Ex. 1, at 8; Sherman Dec., at ยถ 6. 
16    On May 16, 2018, Livingston submitted an emergency grievance stating he requested a 
17  Ramadan meal in a kiosk message and had not received the meal. In the grievance, Livingston 
18  stated he was on a Halal diet and that he โhad received it but not my meal for when I break my 
19  fast after sundown.โ ECF No. 17, Maxson Dec., at ยถ 9. Maxson interviewed Livingston about 
20  his grievance on May 22, 2018, asking why he did not sign up at WCC. Id. Livingston said he 
21  was in segregation and never saw a posting. Id. Upon further questioning, Livingston indicated 
22  he knew about the sign up process from being in prison before. Id. Maxson explained there was 
23  no record of Livingston signing up for Ramadan as was required and asked Livingston whether 
24  he agreed his grievance was resolved on this basis. Id. Livingston stated that he โguessed that it 
25  was  resolvedโ  but  believed  DOC  still  had  to  feed  him.  Id.  The  grievance  was  marked 
26  informally resolved and Livingston did not appeal this decision. ECF No. 17, Maxson Dec, at ยถ 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  9  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 10 of 25
 
1  9 & Ex. 4; Counsel Dec., Ex. 5, at 77:22-23. Commissary records show that he purchased and 
2  received numerous food items from the inmate store in May and early June, including summer 
3  sausage, corn tortillas, and over a case of Ramen. ECF No. 21, Blair Dec., Exs. 4 & 8.  
4 
4.  Plaintiff Naim Lao 
5    Lao entered DOC custody in June 2017 and arrived at MCC in September 2017. ECF 
6  No. 16, Stewart Dec., at ยถ 15; Counsel Dec., Ex. 6, Lao Deposition, at 13:14-24. Chaplain 
7  Sherman sent Lao a copy of a Ramadan meal sign-up form in January 2018. Sherman Dec., at 
8  ยถ 4 & Ex. 1. Lao did not sign up for the Ramadan meal program. Counsel Dec., Ex. 6, at 54:17-
9  23. On May 17, 2018, Lao sent a kiosk message to the Chaplain to ask to get on the Ramadan 
10  List to receive meals. ECF No. 20-1, at 14. The Chaplain responded that he could add Lao to 
11  the daily prayer but not the fast list because Lao needed to sign up by January 30, 2018. Id. Lao 
12  sent a kiosk message to the Chaplain a few days later complaining he was not on the daily 
13  prayer list and the chaplain responded that Lao had been placed on the callout list for prayer. 
14  Id. On May 23, 2018, Lao received an exception and was added to the Ramadan Meal List and 
15  began receiving meals. Stewart Dec. ยถ 15; Counsel Dec., Ex. 6, at 57:1-4.  
16 
5.  Plaintiff John James  
17    James has been incarcerated since the early 1990s. Counsel Dec., Ex. 7, at 38:24-25. 
18  James  transferred  to  MCC  on  January  2,  2018.  Counsel  Dec.,  Ex.  7,  at  8:4-18.  Shortly 
19  thereafter, James became one of the inmate leaders for Jummah. Counsel Dec., Ex. 7, at 26:18-
20  22. James has been on a gluten free to treat a medical condition. Counsel Dec., Ex. 7, at 81:16-

22  (1986). To determine if summary judgment is appropriate, the court must consider whether a 
23  particular fact is material and whether there is a genuine dispute as to that material fact left to 
24  be resolved. Fed. R. Civ. P. 56(c). If the nonmoving party bears the burden of proof at trial, the 
25  moving party is not required to bring forth any additional evidence in support of the motion as 
26  long as the motion demonstrates the absence of genuine disputes of material facts and that the

A.  Plaintiffs Failed to Exhaust Their Claims 
6    Incarcerated individuals are required to properly exhaust their administrative remedies 
7  before bringing lawsuits about prison conditions. 42 U.S.C. ยง 1997e(a). Inmates must not only 
8  fully exhaust available administrative remedies, but they also must exhaust those remedies in a 
9  timely manner and abide by the administrative rules governing the internal grievance process. 
10  Woodford v. Ngo, 548 U.S. 81, 83 (2006). To effectively exhaust his administrative remedies, 
11  an inmate must use all the formal steps of the prison grievance process. Griffin v. Arpaio, 557 
12  F.3d 1117, 1119 (9th Cir. 2009). Exhaustion must be accomplished prior to the filing of the 
13  lawsuit. McKinney v. Carey, 311 F.3d 1198, 1199 (9th Cir. 2002) (requiring dismissal when 
14  exhaustion was ongoing).  But see Cano v. Taylor, 739 F.3d  1214, 1220 (9th Cir. 2014) 
15  (indicating that exhaustion is proper when a claim is exhausted between the filing of the 
16  original  complaint  and  the  filing  of  the  amended  complaint).  RLUIPA  incorporates  the 
17  PLRAโs exhaustion requirements. Fuqua v. Ryan, 890 F.3d 838, 844 (9th Cir. 2018). 
18    When prison officials move for summary judgment based on exhaustion, they bear the 
19  initial burden of showing that there was an available administrative remedy and that the 
20  plaintiff did not exhaust that administrative remedy. Albino v. Baca, 747 F.3d 1162, 1172 (9th 
21  Cir. 2014). If prison officials make such a showing, a prisoner can overcome the exhaustion 
22  defense by producing evidence showing that the administrative remedies were effectively 
23  unavailable to him. Id. If the evidence shows that the remedies were available and the inmate 
24  failed to properly exhaust such remedies, the inmateโs claims must be dismissed. 
25    Here, four of the Plaintiffs (Roberts, Mohamed, Lao, and Livingston) failed to pursue 
26  their grievances through all of the stages of the grievance program. Mohamed and Lao did not

B.  Plaintiffsโ RLUIPA Claims Are Moot 
10  Plaintiffsโ RLUIPA claims seek only injunctive and declaratory relief.4 Three of the 
11  five plaintiffs (Mohamed, Livingston, and Lao) no longer are in prison. Their RLUIPA claims 
12  are therefore moot. โAn inmateโs release from prison while his claims are pending generally 
13  will moot any claims for injunctive relief relating to the prisonโs policies unless the suit has 
14  been certified as a class action.โ Alvarez v. Hill, 667 F.3d 1061, 1064 (9th Cir. 2012) (quoting 
15  from Dilley v. Gunn, 64 F.3d 1365, 1368 (9th Cir. 1995)). โThe same is true for claims seeking 
16  declaratory relief.โ Id. (citing Rhodes v. Stewart, 488 U.S. 1, 2-4 (1988)).  
17  There are two, narrow exceptions to mootness, neither of which applies here. The first 
18  exception applies when the claims are capable of repetition, yet will continue to evade review. 
19  This exception โis limited to extraordinary cases in which (1) the duration of the challenged 
20  action is too short to be fully litigated before it ceases, and (2) there is a reasonable expectation 
21  that the plaintiff will be subjected to the same action again.โ Id. (quoting from C.F. ex rel. 
22  Farnan v. Capistrano Unified Sch. Dist., 654 F.3d 975, 983 (9th Cir. 2011). Notably, a plaintiff 
23  who releases from prison has no reasonable expectation of returning to prison for purposes of

1  C.  Mootness Aside, Plaintiffs Do Not Have Viable RLUIPA Claims 
2  Even if Plaintiffsโ RLUIPA claims were not moot, the claims fail on the merits as a 
3  matter of law. RLUIPA prohibits state correctional facilities from substantially burdening 
4  inmatesโ religious exercise unless the burden furthers a compelling government interest and 
5  does so by the least restrictive means. 42 U.S.C. ยง 2000cc-1(1)-(2). Under RLUIPA, the inmate 
6  bears the initial burden to show a prima facie case that the government regulation imposes a 
7  substantial burden on the exercise of his religious beliefs. Warsoldier v. Woodford, 418 F.3d 
8  989, 994 (9th Cir. 2005). Plaintiffs cannot meet that burden here because the Ramadan meal 
9  signup process they challenge is not a substantial burden on their religious exercise. Moreover, 
10  even if it were a substantial burden, the signup process serves a compelling government 
11  interest โ allowing DOC to plan for, procure, and prepare sufficient meals to meet the demand 
12  for the Ramadan observance โ and is the least restrictive means to achieve that interest.   
13  1.  The Sign-up Process Does Not Impose a Substantial Burden  
14  โ[A] burden is substantial under RLUIPA when the state denies [an important benefit] 
15  because of conduct mandated by religious belief, thereby putting substantial pressure on an 
16  adherent to modify his behavior and to violate his beliefs.โ Shakur v. Schriro, 514 F.3d 878, 
17  888 (9th Cir. 2008) (internal quotes omitted). Requiring an inmate to sign a piece of paper or 
18  submit a form requesting to participate in a religious activity does not impose a substantial 
19  burden on the inmateโs religious practices. See Resnick v. Adams, 348 F.3d 763, 768 n.6 (9th 
20  Cir. 2003). โ[R]egistration places, at most, a slight burden on an inmateโs right to religious 
21  freedom while serving as an important and beneficial โbright lineโ that enables prison officials 
22  to ascertain the seriousness of the inmateโs religious commitment and respond accordingly.โ 
23  Jackson-Bey v. Hansimaier, 115 F.3d 1091, 1097 (2d Cir. 1997).  
24  Indeed, absent some requirement that inmates notify prison officials of their desire to 
25  participate in religious festivities, it would be impossible for prison staff to accommodate such 
26  requests. Therefore, DOCโs requirement that Plaintiffs sign up to receive Ramadan meals does

25    It is only โโthe unnecessary and wanton infliction of painโ . . . [which] constitutes cruel 
26  and unusual punishment forbidden by the Eighth Amendment.โ Whitley v. Albers, 475 U.S. 312,

1  319 (1986) (citing Ingraham v. Wright, 430 U.S. 651, 670 (1977)). The Eighth Amendment 
2  standard requires proof of both an objective and a subjective component. Hudson v. McMillian, 
3  503 U.S. 1 (1992). The objective component of an Eighth Amendment claim requires that the 
4  deprivation must be โsufficiently serious.โ Farmer v. Brennan, 511 U.S. 825, 834 (1994). The 
5  subjective component relates to the defendantโs state of mind, and requires deliberate indifference. 
6  Farmer, 511 U.S. at 834. In this case, Plaintiffsโ claims fail to meet both prongs. 
7    To be objectively, sufficiently serious, an individual must have been deprived of the 
8  minimal civilized measure of lifeโs necessities. Rhodes v. Chapman, 452 U.S. 337, 347 (1981). 
9  Although  inmates  have  a  right  to  adequate  food,  the  food  does  not  need  to  be  tasty  or 
10  aesthetically pleasing. See LeMaire v. Maass, 12 F.3d 1444, 1456 (9th Cir. 1993); Williams v. 
11  Berge, 102 Fed. Appโx 506, 507 (7th Cir. 2004) (inmate being served stale raisins and moldy 
12  peanut butter with other food was not an Eighth Amendment violation). Additionally, as long 
13  as an inmate is being provided adequate food, it does not matter the manner in which prisons 
14  deliver that food. See LeMaire, 12 F.3d at 1456; Green v. Ferrell, 801 F.2d 765, 770-71 (5th 
15  Cir. 1986) (two meals per day was adequate); Griffis v. Gundy, 47 Fed. Appโx 327, 328 (6th 
16  Cir. 2002) (diet of food loaf did not violate Eighth Amendment when loaf met nutritional and 
17  caloric requirements). Repeated  and unjustified failures to  provide inmates with  adequate 
18  sustenance could rise to the level of an Eighth Amendment violation. See Mendiola-Martinez 
19  v. Arpaio, 836 F.3d 1239, 1259 (9th Cir. 2016); Foster v. Runnels, 554 F.3d 807, 814 (9th Cir. 
20  2009). However, the Eighth Amendment is not violated when prison officials place reasonable 
21  conditions on receiving meals. Freeman v. Berge, 441 F.3d 543, 545 (7th Cir. 2006). 
22    The four Plaintiffs who were not on the Ramadan menu were not denied food adequate 
23  to meet their nutritional needs because each had the option to get mainline food. To the extent 
24  they argue the mainline meals did not meet their needs because of their sincerely held religious 
25  beliefs, that claim is more properly analyzed under RLUIPA or the First Amendment, not the 
26  Eighth Amendment. To the extent any of these four plaintiffs now try to raise an eleventh hour

E.  Plaintiff Have Failed to Show a Viable Free Exercise Claim 
6    For  a  prisoner  to  satisfy  a  First  Amendment  religious  claim,  he  โmust  show  the 
7  [defendant]  burdened  the  practice  of  [his]  religion,  by  preventing  him  from  engaging  in 
8  conduct  mandated  by  his  faith,  without  any  justification  reasonably  related  to  legitimate 
9  penological interests.โ Freeman v. Arpaio, 125 F.3d 732, 735 (9th Cir. 1997) (citing Turner v. 
10  Safley, 482 U.S. 78, 89, 107 S. Ct. 2254 (1987). The Turner court provided four factors to 
11  guide reviewing courts in determining the reasonableness of the regulation. โFirst, there must 
12  be a โvalid, rational connectionโ between the prison regulation and the legitimate governmental 
13  interest put forward to justify it.โ Id. (citations omitted). A second factor is โwhether there are 
14  alternative means of exercising the rights that remain open to prison inmates.โ Id. at 90. The 
15  third consideration is the โimpact accommodation of the asserted constitutional right will have 
16  on guards and other inmates, and the allocation of prison resources generally.โ Id. Last, the 
17  โabsence of ready alternatives is evidence of the reasonableness of the regulation.โ Id. 
18    Because RLUIPA provides greater protection than the First Amendment, a policy that 
19  survives  RLUIPA  analysis  also  survives  a  First  Amendment  challenge.  Florer  v.  Bales-
20  Johnson, 752 F. Supp. 2d 1185, 1202 (W.D. Wash. 2010). Because Defendantsโ actions did not 
21  violate  RLUIPA  for  the  reasons  discussed  above,  they  also  did  not  violate  the  First 
22  Amendment. Even if the Court were to find a triable RLUIPA claim, dismissal of the First 
23  Amendment claims would be appropriate. Plaintiffsโ First Amendment claims fail because the 
24  sign-up process does not impose a burden or prevent an inmate from exercising their faith.  
25    Even  assuming,  for  the  sake  of  argument,  that  the  Ramadan  signup  process  does 
26  impose a burden, the process would still be constitutional because it is reasonably related to 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  20  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 21 of 25
 
1  legitimate penological interests. DOCโs sign-up process is ultimately designed to ensure that 
2  DOC has accurate numbers of Ramadan participants to allow it effectively plan to provide the 
3  Ramadan  meal  program.  Cf.  Walker  v.  Beard,  789  F.3d  1125,  1138  (9th  Cir.  2015) 
4  (recognizing  avoiding  potential  legal  liability  as  a  legitimate  penological  interest).  As 
5  discussed above, the sign-up process is simple and the burden on an inmateโs exercise of their 
6  religion is minimal, if any. There is a logical and rational connection between this sign-up 
7  process and the goal of ensuring DOC can adequately provide enough food. Furthermore, if 
8  inmates do not wish to participate in the Ramadan meal program, there are alternative ways for 
9  inmates to practice their faith, including by fasting and breaking the fast with food purchased 
10  through the commissary, participating in the Ramadan prayer, or participating in other Islamic 
11  activities. The absence of a sign-up process will harm other inmates because it will create the 
12  potential that DOC be unable to plan adequately for Ramadan and run short of Ramadan meals. 
13  It will also create confusion and an increased burden on prison guards and kitchen staff who 
14  help administrate the Ramadan meal program.  There is no evidence that DOCโs sign up 
15  process is an exaggerated response to these concerns. Finally, with respect to Jamesโ claims, 
16  prison officials do not violate the First Amendment by providing regular Ramadan meals to an 
17  inmate on a therapeutic diet. Payne v. Doe, 636 Fed Appโx 120, 124 (3d Cir. 2016). Therefore, 
18  Plaintiffs do not have viable First Amendment claims and such claims should be dismissed. 
19 
F.  Plaintiffs Have Failed to Show a Viable Equal Protection Claim 
20    The  Equal  Protection  Clause  โis  essentially  a  direction  that  all  persons  similarly 
21  situated should be treated alike.โ City of Cleburne, Tex. v. Cleburne Living Center, 473 U.S. 
22  432, 439 (1985). An Equal Protection claim requires an individual to โshow intentional or 
23  purposeful discrimination.โ See Washington v. Davis, 426 U.S. 229, 239 (1976); Draper v. Rhay, 
24  315 F.2d 193, 198 (9th Cir. 1963). The Equal Protection Clause, however, does not require 
25  absolute equality among inmates. Bruce v. Ylst, 351 F.3d 1283, 1288 (9th Cir. 2003). To 
26  survive summary judgment, an inmate must show he was not afforded a reasonable opportunity 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  21  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 22 of 25
 
1  to pursue his faith compared to prisoners of other faiths and that such conduct was intentional. 
2  Freeman v. Arpaio, 125 F.3d 732 (9th Cir. 1997), overruled in part by Shakur v. Schriro, 514 
3  F.3d 878, 884 (9th Cir. 2008).  If an inmate establishes that prison officials  intentionally 
4  discriminated based on an inmateโs religion, prison officials must bring forth some justification 
5  about the reason for the distinction. The Ninth Circuit has applied the Turner test to inmatesโ 
6  equal protection claims based on alleged religious discrimination. Shakur v. Schriro, 514 F.3d 
7  878, 891 (9th Cir. 2008).5 
8    There is no evidence to support the claim that Muslim inmates were treated differently 
9  than other similarly situated inmates. All DOC inmates were required to follow the same sign-
10  up process to participate in Ramadan, and there is no evidence that the sign-up process for 
11  Ramadan is more onerous than the sign-up process for Passover or other religious events. See 
12  Counsel Dec., Ex. 8, at 201:24-202:8. Assuming that inmates signed up through the process, 
13  Muslim  inmates  were  given  food  that  met  the  daily  calorie  requirements,  just  like  other 
14  inmates in DOC custody. Therefore, Plaintiffs are not able to show that they were treated 
15  differently than similarly situated inmates based on their religion. Furthermore, to the extent 
16  that Plaintiffs can claim that there are differential treatment, such treatment serves legitimate 
17  penological goals for the reasons discussed in the prior section.  
18 
G.  Plaintiffsโ  Money  Damage  Claims  Fail  Because  Defendants  Are  Entitled  to 
Qualified Immunity 
19 
 
20    In determining whether defendants are entitled to qualified immunity, the court makes a 
21  two-step inquiry. First, the court determines if plaintiff has shown that defendants violated his 
22  constitutional rights. Saucier v. Katz, 533 U.S. 194, 201 (2001), overruled on other grounds by 
                                                 
23 
5 The level of scrutiny is not entirely clear in terms of equal protection claims related to alleged religious 
discrimination. Some district courts, at least in unpublished cases, in the Ninth Circuit have suggested that strict 
24 
scrutiny applies to equal protection claims related to religious discrimination. See, e.g., Black v. Hansen, Cause 
No. 11-2782-CMK-P, 2015 WL 1294965, at *7 (E.D. Cal. March 23, 2015). However, the Ninth Circuit has not 
25 
said that explicitly and has applied Turner in cases like Shakur. The Court need not settle this question to resolve 
this case because even if the Court were to apply strict scrutiny, Plaintiffs have failed to show intentional 
26 
discrimination and the Ramadan meal programโs simple sign-up process would survive strict scrutiny. 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  22  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 23 of 25
 
1  Pearson v. Callahan, 555 U.S. 223 (2009). Second, the court must determine if the right was 
2  clearly established. Id. This requires the court to determine if it would have been clear to a 
3  reasonable officer that his conduct was unlawful in the situation he confronted. Id. at 202. For 
4  a  right  to  be  clearly  established,  โexisting  precedent  must  have  placed  the  statutory  or 
5  constitutional  question  beyond  debate.โ  Reichle  v.  Howards,  566  U.S.  658,  664  (2012) 
6  (quoting Ashcroft v. al-Kidd, 563 U.S. 731, 741 (2011)). The plaintiff bears the burden of 
7  proving that the right was clearly established. See Davis v. Scherer, 468 U.S. 183, 197 (1984).  
8    Because Plaintiffs have failed to present viable claims of constitutional violations for 
9  the reasons discussed above, Defendants are entitled to qualified immunity. Even if Plaintiffs 
10  could  raise  viable  constitutional  claims,  Defendants  would  still  be  entitled  to  qualified 
11  immunity because the law is not clearly established. There is no clearly established case law 
12  holding that prisons violate the First Amendment by requiring inmates to sign up in advance to 
13  participate in Ramadan. In fact, the published Ninth Circuit cases suggest otherwise.  See 
14  Resnick v. Adams, 348 F.3d 763, 771 (9th Cir. 2003) (concluding application requirement to 
15  receive religious diet did not violate First Amendment). And this Court has rejected similar 
16  challenges to similar sign-up requirements. See Williams v. Fluiatt, No. CV-12-5017-JTR, 
17  2013 WL 6795947 (E.D. Wash. Dec. 23, 2013); McDaniels v. Sherman, No. 09-1296-JCC, 
18  2011 WL 197441 (W.D. Wash. Jan. 21, 2011). There is also no published case law that 
19  suggests Defendants were required to create a therapeutic Ramadan diet for James or that they 
20  violated the First Amendment by declining to offer a gluten free Ramadan meal in 2018. See 
21  Payne v. Doe, 636 Fed Appโx 120, 124 (3d Cir. 2016); see also Leggett v. Solomon, No. 14-
22  CT-3228-FL, 2017 WL 421915, at *4 (E.D.N.C. Jan. 31, 2017). With respect to Plaintiffsโ 
23  Eighth Amendment claims, courts have rejected similar claims and Plaintiffs will be unable to 
24  point to a consensus of authority on this issue. Finally, although Plaintiffsโ equal protection 
25  claims are somewhat difficult to decipher, Plaintiffs will be unable to point to any case law that 
26  clearly establishes that having a sign-up process violates the Equal Protection Clause. See 
 
 
DEFENDANTSโ MOTION FOR  23  ATTORNEY GENERAL OF WASHINGTON 
Corrections Division 
SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
PO Box 40116 
NO. 2:18-CV-00837-RSM-BAT   Olympia, WA 98504-0116 
(360) 586-1445 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 73   Filed 07/09/19   Page 24 of 25
 
1  Garnica v. Wash. Depโt of Corr., 965 F. Supp. 2d 1250, 1275 (W.D. Wash. 2013) (rejecting 
2  equal protection challenge to Ramadan meal program). Therefore, Defendants are entitled to 
3  qualified immunity and Plaintiffsโ claims for monetary damages must be dismissed. 
4 
H.  Plaintiffs Do Not Have a Viable Claim for Injunctive Relief Under Section 1983  
5    In addition to meeting the traditional requirements for injunctive relief, a party seeking 
6  a permanent injunction must actually succeed on the merits. See e.g., Valley View Health Care 
7  Inc. v. Chapman, 992 F. Supp. 2d 1016, 1042 (E.D. Cal. 2014). An inmateโs release generally 
8  moots any injunctive relief claim. Dilley v. Gunn, 64 F.3d 1365 (9th Cir. 1995).Three Plaintiffs 
9  (Lao, Livingston, and Mohamed) have released from prison; their claims for injunctive relief 
10  are therefore moot. As to Roberts and James, they are not entitled to injunctive relief because 
11  they cannot show a viable Section 1983 claim on the merits, and their constitutional claims are 
12  also moot for the reasons discussed in Section III.B. Therefore, Plaintiffsโ claims for injunctive 
13  relief must be dismissed. 
14 
IV.  CONCLUSION 
15    Defendants  respectfully  request  that  the  Court  grant  their  motion  for  summary 
16  judgment and dismiss Plaintiffsโ claims with prejudice.   
17    RESPECTFULLY SUBMITTED this 9th day of July, 2019.

1  NOTICE OF MOTION FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
2  TO ALL DEFENDANTS AND THEIR COUNSEL:  Please take notice that as soon as the 
3  matter may be heard in the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington, 
4  Plaintiffs DAMARIO ROBERTS (Inmate #398950), MOHAMED MOHAMED (Inmate # 
5  384454), JEREMY LIVINSTON (Inmate #381036), NAIM LAO (Inmate # 381036), and JOHN 
6  JAMES (Inmate # 712756) shall and hereby do move the Court for Summary Judgment as to 
7  Liability and Permanent Injunctive Relief.  Plaintiffs seek the entry of summary judgment against 
8  Defendants STEPHEN SINCLAIR, BELINDA STEWART, JAMIE DOLAN, MIKE OBELAND, 
9  JEFF UTTECHT, DAVID SHERMAN, HENRI FISCHER, PETE MAXSON, SERGEANT 
10  PARKS, and SERGEANT ROSE.  This motion is brought pursuant to Federal Rule of Civil 
11  Procedure 56, 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, the First Amendment, the Eighth Amendment, the Fourteenth 
12  Amendment, and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act, 42 U.S.C. ยง 2000cc et seq.  
13  Defendants violated these provisions by implementing policies, procedures, and practices which 
14  deprived Plaintiffs of adequate meals during Ramadan 2018.  
15  Plaintiffsโ motion is based upon their Amended Complaint (Dkt. 59), this notice of motion, 
16  the accompanying memorandum of points and authorities, the deposition transcripts and exhibits in 
17  support, and all such further written materials and oral arguments as may be presented to the Court. 
18  The Court should enter summary judgment finding liability against all Official-Capacity Defendants 
19  and award declaratory and injunctive relief.  The Government should also enter summary judgment 
20  against all Individual-Capacity Defendants.  Further proceedings should relate solely to Plaintiffsโ 
21  damages and entitlement to attorneysโ fees. 
22 
Respectfully submitted, 
 
23

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 79-1   Filed 07/09/19   Page 4 of 24
 
1  INTRODUCTION 
2  One of the five pillars of Islam is that Muslims fast during Ramadan.  Plaintiffs Damario 
3  Roberts, Mohamed Mohamed, Jeremy Livingston, Naim Lao, and John James are all sincere Muslims 
4  who observe the Ramadan fast.  But Defendants, all officials and employees of the Washington 
5  Department of Corrections, refused to feed them accordingly.  So when given the choice between 
6  starving and violating their religious faith, Plaintiffs chose to starve.  Fasting during the day and 
7  unable to eat at night, Plaintiffs lost significant weight and became sick with malnourishment. They 
8  were forced to purchase their own food and beg for other inmates to share food, against policy, to 
9  survive.  They did this all because Defendants imposed, and continue to impose, onerous and 
10  intrusive requirements for inmates to participate in Ramadan.   
11  These requirements are illegal.  They are without justification.  Defendants did not refuse to 
12  feed Plaintiffs because it was too difficult.  They acknowledge they always have enough food on 
13  hand, and that itโs easy to take a halal meal out of the freezer, heat it up after sunset, and feed fasting 
14  Muslim inmates.  Instead Defendants refused to feed Plaintiffs because of their irrational, 
15  bureaucratic policies.  After all, the Defendants reasoned, it was Plaintiffsโ choice to starve.  
16  Defendants gave themselves discretion to disagree with Plaintiffsโ religious beliefs, suggesting โAllah 
17  is all mercifulโ and will forgive Plaintiffs if โ due to Defendantsโ refusal to provide Ramadan meals โ 
18  Plaintiffs violate their faith by eating lunch.   
19  The U.S. Constitution and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act forbid 
20  the Washington Department of Corrections from substituting the Governmentโs discretionary 
21  opinions regarding religious accommodations for Muslimsโ actual religious practice of Ramadan.  The 
22  Department is required to accommodate fasting inmates, not starve them.   
23  This Court should enter summary judgment on liability against all Defendants and enjoin the 
24  WSDOC from adopting or implementing any policy which prevents Muslim inmates from fasting 
25  during any future Ramadan. 
26  STATEMENT OF MATERIAL UNDISPUTED FACTS 
27  A.  Plaintiffsโ Sincere Religious Beliefs Require Fasting During Ramadan 
28  1.  All the Plaintiffs are practicing Muslims who sincerely believe that observing the 
    - 1 -   
PLAINTIFFSโ MEMORANDUM ISO SUMMARY JUDGMENT

ARGUMENT 
14 
In ruling on a motion under Rule 56, summary judgment is appropriate when โthere is no 
15 
genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of 
16 
law.โ Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 247 (1986). 
17 
I.  Defendantsโ Ramadan Policies and Practices Violate RLUIPA 
18 
For reasons no greater than marginal administrative convenience, knowing the pain it will cause 
19 
the many Muslim inmates who observe Ramadanโs fast, Defendants deprived Plaintiffs of food.  In 
20 
doing so, they violate RLUIPA, the law Congress passed to ensure prisons and jails across the country 
21 
allow inmates in custody to practice their faith.   
22 
A.  RLUIPA Requires Defendants to Accommodate Ramadan Fasting 
23 
  RLUIPA exists to make it illegal for the Department to do what it has done here: deprive 
24 
Muslim inmates of food, and sometimes even water, between sunset and dawn so the inmates may 
25 
observe the Ramadan fast during the day.  Section 3 of the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized 
26 
Persons Act of 2000, 42 U.S.C. ยง 2000cc creates a private cause of action for such persons who allege 
27 
that a state government has substantially burdened their religious conduct. 42 U.S.C. ยง 2000cc-1(a), 
28 
    - 10 -   
PLAINTIFFSโ MEMORANDUM ISO SUMMARY JUDGMENT 
 

Case 2:18-cv-00837-RSM   Document 79-1   Filed 07/09/19   Page 14 of 24
 
1  2(a).  Unlike cases arising under the Free Exercise Clause of the First Amendment, RLUIPA applies 
2  even where the burden on the prisoner โresults from a rule of general applicability.โ  42 U.S.C. ยง 
3  2000cc-1(a).  
4    To establish a claim under RLUIPA, a plaintiff bears the initial burden of showing (1) that he 
5  seeks to engage in an exercise of religion, and (2) that the challenged practice substantially burdens that 
6  exercise of religion. 42 U.S.C. ยง 2000cc-2(b). Once a plaintiff has established this prima facie case, a 
7  defendant bears the burden of proving that imposition of the burden is in โfurtherance of a compelling 
8  governmental interestโ and โis the least restrictive means of furthering that compelling governmental 
9  interest.โ  42 U.S.C. ยง 2000cc-1(a)(1)-(2). 
10  B.  All Plaintiffs Are and Were Muslims who Adhere to One of the Five Pillars of 
11  Islam Directing Adherents to Fast During Ramadan

22  established.โ Foster v. Runnels, 554 F.3d 807, 815 (9th Cir. 2009).  Defendants have always known that, 
23  as the government officials who exercise control over Plaintiffs during their incarceration, it is their
